Package IntroductionChallenges

  • Class Summary 
    Class Description
    JavaCurrencyFormatter
    Given a double-precision number,payment , denoting an amount of money, use the NumberFormat class' getCurrencyInstance method to convert payment into the US, Indian, Chinese, and French currency formats.
    JavaDatatypes
    Java has 8 primitive data types; char, boolean, byte, short, int, long, float, and double.
    JavaDateAndTime
    The Calendar class is an abstract class that provides methods for converting between a specific instant in time and a set of calendar fields such as YEAR, MONTH, DAY_OF_MONTH, HOUR, and so on, and for manipulating the calendar fields, such as getting the date of the next week.
    JavaEndOfFile
    The challenge here is to read n lines of input until you reach EOF, then number and print all n lines of content.
    JavaIfElse
    In this challenge, we test your knowledge of using if-else conditional statements to automate decision-making processes.
    JavaIntToString
    You are given an integer n, you have to convert it into a string.
    JavaLoops_I
    Objective
    In this challenge, we're going to use loops to help us do some simple math.
    JavaLoops_II
    We use the integers a, b, and n to create the following series:

    (a + 22.b),(a + 20.b + 21.b), ... , (a + 20.b + 21.b + ... + 2n-2)

    You are given q queries in the form of a,b, and n.
    JavaOutputFormatting
    Java's System.out.printf function can be used to print formatted output.
    JavaStaticInitializerBlock
    Static initialization blocks are executed when the class is loaded, and you can initialize static variables in those blocks.
    JavaStdinAndStdout_I
    Most HackerRank challenges require you to read input from stdin (standard input) and write output to stdout (standard output).
    JavaStdinAndStdout_II
    In this challenge, you must read an integer, a double, and a String from stdin, then print the values according to the instructions in the Output Format section below.
    WelcomeToJava
    Welcome to the world of Java!
